update.description:
Two main issues:

* We were allocating an object of type hxsSimInfo on the stack. It turns out that hxsSimInfo is pretty big and we overflow the memory in the stack. Thanks to @gerkey for catching the problem.

* There's no way to use std::system on Windows to execute a non blocking command unless you use `start ` as a prefix. This will create a new `cmd` windows and run your command without blocking.

CI Results:

* [Here](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/proj_haptix/job/haptix_comm-any-devel-windows7-amd64/7/) is our Jenkins job (pending).
update.title: Fix tests on Windows

content.raw: I haven't look into this yet.
We just noticed a few exceptions running the tests on Windows.
content.html: We just noticed a few exceptions running the tests on Windows.

content.raw: Carlos, still no luck on getting the build to work on the Windows jenkins slave?
content.html: Carlos, still no luck on getting the build to work on the Windows jenkins slave?

content.raw: This was the same problem that we found the first time we implemented the mex files, that made the whole thing to hang, right?
content.html: This was the same problem that we found the first time we implemented the mex files, that made the whole thing to hang, right?

update.description:
Two main issues:

* We were allocating an object of type hxsSimInfo on the stack. It turns out that hxsSimInfo is pretty big and we overflow the memory in the stack. Thanks to @gerkey for catching the problem.

* There's no way to use std::system on Windows to execute a non blocking command unless you use `start ` as a prefix. This will create a new `cmd` windows and run your command without blocking.

CI Results:

* [Here](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/proj_haptix/job/haptix_comm-any-devel-windows7-amd64/7/) is our Jenkins job (pending).
